thread.title: Jarin takes blame for Game 1 loss
thread.title_full: Jarin takes blame for Game 1 loss | mb.com.ph | Philippine News

author: Christian Jacinto
title: Jarin takes blame for Game 1 loss
text:
by Christian Jacinto
October 25, 2015 Games Tuesday
(Mall of Asia Arena)
2 p.m. – San Beda vs Arellano
(Juniors game two, San Beda leads 1-0)
4 p.m. – San Beda vs Letran
(Seniors game two, Letran leads 1-0)
In the wake of San Beda’s 94-90 loss to rival Letran in the first game of the NCAA basketball tournament finals, San Beda Red Lions head coach Jamike Jarin puts the blame on no one but himself.
The outspoken, multi-titled mentor got outcoached by the Knights’ rookie coach Aldin Ayo in a game which was expected to favor the heavily experienced and talented titleholders.
With him failing to adjust to Letran’s defensive schemes and his players unable to match Letran’s energy, the Red Lions succumbed to just their second Game One loss in a decade, with the lone loss coming against the Calvin Abueva-led San Sebastian Stags in 2009.
Eerily, San Beda lost that series.
“I coached bad today so it’s my fault. That’s why we lost. In all aspects, I wasn’t able to prepare against Letran,” said Jarin in the post-match press conference.
With Ayo’s so-called “House of Chaos” in full effect once more, the five-time champions turned the ball over 29 times allowing Letran to score 25 points off those miscues.
“We had too many turnovers. We had our chances and we weren’t able to execute and I take the blame for that. I failed to coach the right way,” he added.
While they were busy turning the ball over, the Knights’ veteran quartet immediately went to work as Kevin Racal exploded for a season best 28 points.
Rey Nambatac added 18, Mark Cruz finished with 17 while McJour Luib added 16 to add to the Lions’ woes.
All four of these players were part of the Knights squad which lost in three games against San Beda in 2013. Cruz and Racal were even part of the 2012 Letran team which succumbed to the Red Lions in humiliating fashion, losing 67-39 in Game Three of the finals.
But all’s not lost for Jarin as he believes that they can still turn things around assuming they match the Knights effort and make the right decisions.
